page.title: 10LOCAL HISTORY
page.content: {LOCAL HISTORY }Area could have been settled as early as 500 B.C. Roman invasion of AD.43 started the crossing of the Trent at Littleborough or Segelocum with the road leading from Doncaster to Lincoln. The name Leverton suggests Saxon origin probably a croft left by the Romans and developed by Saxons invading by the Trent. Legreton was its name in the Domesday Book. Habbblesthorpe was a seperate parish with church keeping a paid prebend in York minster with the name Appesthorpe. Leverton has a seat in the chapter house at Southwell Minster. The flooding of the Trent side vilages was decreased in 1769 by the building of banks on the Trent and the digging of the catch water drain from Rampton to West Burton.
